channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Head of Sweden’s Karolinska Institute Quits Over Transplant Scandal
item.description: Anders Hamsten said he could no longer lead the the institute after accusations of medical misconduct against a former professor there.
item.dc:creator: HENRY FOUNTAIN

item.title: U.S. Plans to Resume Commercial Flights to Cuba This Year
item.description: An agreement to be completed next week will allow American carriers to offer 20 flights per day to Havana and dozens more to other Cuban cities.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Many Asians Express Dismay and Frustration After Liang Verdict
item.description: In Asian enclaves of New York, residents objected to the guilty verdict of Officer Peter Liang, saying that he was a scapegoat because of his race.
item.dc:creator: SARAH MASLIN NIR and DAVID W. CHEN
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vendors in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, a neighborhood with a large Asian population. Many residents objected on Thursday to the guilty verdict for Officer Peter Liang, who is Chinese-American.

item.title: Death of Student, Giulio Regeni, Highlights Perils for Egyptians, Too
item.description: If Mr. Regeni had not been Italian, his brutal death in Egypt might have been just one of many there that are treated indifferently.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM, NOUR YOUSSEF and DECLAN WALSH
item.media:credit: Alberto Lancia/Agenzia Nazionale Stampa Associata, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Giulio Regeni’s funeral in Fiumicello, Northern Italy, on Friday.

item.title: Bill Richardson Aids Effort to Free Student Held in North Korea
item.description: The former New Mexico governor, who has helped negotiate the release of Americans imprisoned by Pyongyang, was assisting in the case of Otto Warmbier.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Syria Truce Deal Makes Aid a Political Tool, Critics Say
item.description: Access to aid is enshrined in international law. But in Syria, humanitarian groups say, it is used as leverage in battle and negotiations.
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Displaced people in northern Syria. The United Nations said that nearly 500,000 are under siege and without supplies.

item.title: Anxiety Rises in Mexico as the Peso Tumbles
item.description: The Mexican currency has fallen more than 30 percent against the dollar over the past year, and past collapses have led to deep recessions.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: An oil drilling rig near Veracruz operated by Pemex, Mexico’s state-owned oil company. The global drop in oil prices had decreased government revenue and prompted budget cuts.

item.title: France to Dismantle Part of Migrant Camp Near Calais
item.description: The plan, announced Friday, involves the evacuation of nearly 1,000 people, who are to be resettled in state-run shelters.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.media:description: The migrant camp in Calais, France, last week.

item.title: Pope and Russian Orthodox Leader Meet in Historic Step
item.description: As the pope approached the Russian patriarch, Francis was overheard to say, “Brother.” A moment later, he added, “Finally.”
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY

item.title: Death Toll From War in Syria Now 470,000, Group Finds
item.description: A report by the Syrian Center for Policy Research said life expectancy in Syria had dropped 14 years and put the war’s economic cost at $255 billion.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Mourners gathered for the funeral at a mosque in Douma, Syria, north of Damascus, for a youth who was killed in a mortar attack on Thursday. At least 470,000 Syrians have died as a result of the war, according to the Syrian Center for Policy Research.

item.title: Latvia Has a New Leader, as Fears of Russia and Migration Rise
item.description: The new prime minister is Maris Kucinskis, who must wrestle with an anti-immigrant sentiment and concern over Russian aggression.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD MARTYN-HEMPHILL
item.media:description: Prime Minister Maris Kucinskis at a news conference in Riga, the Latvian capital, on Thursday.

item.title: Venezuela’s Justices Support More Power for the President
item.description: After the Supreme Court approved expanded economic powers for President Nicolás Maduro, the speaker of the National Assembly said a coup had taken place.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: People purchasing scarce cooking oil and powdered milk from a state-run grocery in Puerto Cabello, Venezuela, last month.

item.title: Congressional Memo: For Norway, an Envoy; For Cruz, a Street Name
item.description: Senate stand-ins for Mr. Cruz, who had been blocking the nominees for ambassador, gave the presidential contender what he wanted and ended a long impasse.
item.dc:creator: JENNIFER STEINHAUER
item.media:description: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas spoke to reporters before a vote Wednesday on Capitol Hill. He has helped delay approval of several ambassadors.

item.title: Eurozone Economy Grows, but Total Output Still Lags 2008
item.description: Even as much of the rest of the world has bounced back from the global financial crisis, however fitfully, Europe’s economic core remains soft.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING
item.media:credit: Arnau Bach for The New York Times
item.media:description: The working-class neighborhood of Sant Ildefons in the Catalonia Province of Spain. Greece, Italy and Spain have struggled to recover from the economic crisis of 2008.

item.title: The Independent, Once a British News Power, Will End Its Print Edition
item.description: The paper, which shook up Britain’s journalism establishment in the 1980s before falling on hard times, will publish only online, its owner says.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: The demise of the print editions of The Independent — and its weekly counterpart, The Independent on Sunday — is a blow to Britain’s vibrant and fiercely competitive news media scene.

item.title: In Syria, Skepticism That Cease-Fire Will Stop Fighting
item.description: To many, the deal hammered out in Munich overnight seemed like just another irrelevant set of words dictated by diplomats in a foreign capital.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Syrians waited to cross into Syria at the Oncupinar border crossing in the southeastern city of Kilis, Turkey, on Thursday.

item.title: U.S. Drawing Southeast Asia Closer With California Summit
item.description: Competition with China will be the subtext as President Obama hosts Asean leaders beginning on Monday in Rancho Mirage, Calif.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: President Obama on his way out of the White House. Since his administration’s ‘‘pivot to Asia,’’ America has been in direct competition with China for economic power in Southeast Asia.

item.title: Emoji Maker Finds Muse in a Kim: Jong-un, Not Kardashian West
item.description: A new website allows users to send images of the North Korean leader smiling, crying and walking, as well as rockets and a nuclear mushroom cloud.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH OLIVENNES

item.title: Zika Virus Test Is ‘Weeks, Not Years’ Away, W.H.O. Says
item.description: Large-scale clinical trials for a potential vaccine are not expected for at least 18 months, however, the World Health Organization said.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.media:description: A mother held her 4-month-old son, who was born with microcephaly, in Olinda, Brazil, on Thursday.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Loubna Abidar, Moroccan Actress, Finds Fame Tinged With Fury
item.description: Ms. Abidar, 30, who plays a strong-minded prostitute in the acclaimed film “Much Loved,” was forced to move to France after a backlash at home.
item.dc:creator: AIDA ALAMI
item.media:credit: Pierre Terdjman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Loubna Abidar in Paris this week. Ms. Abidar’s troubles began in May when “Much Loved,” directed by Nabil Ayouch, had its premiere at the Cannes Film Festival.
